title: 115_s3395
content: The "Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act" defines key terms such as Director, Foundation, STEM, and Veteran. It aims to support veterans in STEM education and computer science. The Director of the Foundation is tasked with encouraging veterans to pursue careers in STEM and computer science, in collaboration with other federal agencies. A Veteran Outreach Plan must be submitted within 180 days to enhance outreach efforts to veterans, reporting on existing activities and proposing methods to support veterans in STEM careers and studies. The National Science Board will include data on veterans in STEM careers and education programs in its annual report. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program will be updated to support veterans in STEM teaching programs. The National Science Foundation Teaching Fellowships and Master Teaching Fellowships program is updated to include veterans in STEM education programs. The Cyber Security Research and Development Act is amended to include veterans in computer and network security capacity building grants. This includes creating opportunities for veterans to transition to careers in the field. The Cyber Security Research and Development Act is amended to include veterans in computer and network security grants, creating opportunities for them to transition to STEM careers. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy will establish an interagency working group to coordinate federal programs for training veterans and military spouses in STEM fields. The interagency working group will develop a strategic plan to prioritize objectives and metrics for federal agencies to help veterans and military spouses reenter the workforce, addressing barriers such as lack of STEM education and career guidance. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy will oversee efforts of federal agencies in addressing barriers for military spouses in STEM fields and ensuring the strategic plan is effectively executed. The Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy will ensure the strategic plan is implemented, with a report to Congress due within a year of enactment. The interagency working group will dissolve five years after its establishment.
